qas.question: What other method does Gram-negative bacters use to release material?

answers.text: the formation of outer membrane vesicles

qas.question: What happens with the pinch off part of the outer membrane?

answers.text: , forming spherical structures made of a lipid bilayer enclosing periplasmic materials

qas.question: What does the release of vesicles seem to demenstrate?
What virulence factors do some bacterial species have?

answers.text: some have immunomodulatory effects, and some can directly adhere to and intoxicate host cells

context: In addition to the use of the multiprotein complexes listed above, Gram-negative bacteria possess another method for release of material: <a0_0>the formation of outer membrane vesicles<a0_0/>. Portions of the outer membrane pinch off<a1_0>, forming spherical structures made of a lipid bilayer enclosing periplasmic materials<a1_0/>. Vesicles from a number of bacterial species have been found to contain virulence factors, <a3_0>some have immunomodulatory effects, and some can directly adhere to and intoxicate host cells<a3_0/>. While release of vesicles has been demonstrated as a general <a2_0>response to stress conditions<a2_0/>, the process of loading cargo proteins seems to be selective.
